Description: Pottery: upper part of a small Knidian relief ware flask. The upper part of a flask modelled as a grotesque suffering from spinal tuberculosis (Pott’s Disease). His features are strongly delineated and his hair recedes at the temples, leaving a widow’s peak in the centre. His back is hunched and his ribs are deformed; his arms are at his sides, broken off above the elbow. The head is surmounted by a carinated neck and mouth, and two pierced handles, one of which is broken. Made in a multi-piece mould, probably two-piece. Reduced grey clay.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparandum. For another sufferer from Pott’s Disease, see 3185 in Chapter 3. Bibliog. Pococke 1743: 213, pl. lxiv:E: the right arm has been lost since this illustration was published.
